did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Southwest Folklore Center Cassette Recordings Collection, 1975-1995

origination.label: Creator:
origination.corpname: University of Arizona. Southwest Folklore Center.

did.abstract: Cassette recordings of gospel music, country and western music, Mexican American and Native American music, cowboy songs, and interviews with Arizona residents. Most cassettes are commercially produced.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Restricted. Researchers must use copies of all cassettes when they are available. An item level listing of all cassettes in the collection is available at the end of this document. Duplicates of the cassettes are numbered to correspond to the call numbers of the original cassettes.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Requests for permission to publish from the collection should be discussed with the coordinator of the Southwest Folklore Center or the University of Arizona Manuscripts Librarian. It is the researcher's responsibility to obtain necessary publication rights and copyright clearances for any planned production. Copying of published tapes or records is prohibited.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Southwest Folklore Center Cassette Recordings Collection, 1975-1995(SWF009). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Southwest Folklore Center was founded in 1979 upon the dissolution of the University of Arizona Folklore Committee. Since then it has served as an archive for folklore material. Its activities include actively researching and collecting information about Arizona's folk communities, generating outreach programs, and coordinating folk activities throughout the state.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged according to accession into the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists chiefly of commercially produced cassette recordings of gospel music, country and western music, Native American music and cowboy songs. Performers include many Native American musicians from Arizona. Music performed by Native American musicians and published by Canyon Records of Phoenix, Arizona, comprises a large portion of the cassette recordings. The collection includes cassettes of music written and performed by Lalo Guerrero, Mexican American musician born in Tucson, Arizona.
The collection includes interviews with Arizona residents, folk artists and musicians, and recordings of performances at annual cowboy poetry gatherings.

did.unittitle: Interview with Everett Brisendine, Brisendine, Everett
did.physdesc: Chino Valley, AZ., February 26, 1980; 1 sound cassette, analog
did.abstract: NOTES: Information from acquisitions file... Interview with Everett Brisendine, rawhide braider, cowboy and poet by James S. Griffith and Larry Evers... Transcription of interview includes poems: Just me -- Standin' nightguard -- To a wonderful lady -- In memory of a pardner -- A Cowboy is going to town -- Signs of the times -- The Sub-divisions -- My toeholt in the foothills -- These old hands -- Life is like a game of poker -- Never give up -- My choctaw -- Chuckwagon cook --Collected by James S. Griffith and Larry Evers

did.abstract: NOTES: From acquisition file 80.3: James S. Griffith and Worth Lang interview Reverend Hilaseo Howard of Eloy, Arizona, December 15, 1979... Griffith and Worth Lang

did.unittitle: [Built] on a slim foundation of fact: A look at cowboy humor, James S. Griffith
did.physdesc: [Tucson, AZ., 1983]; 1 sound cassette (28:45 min.), analog
did.abstract: NOTES: From acquisitions file, 83.6: "...copy of the program, 'Built on a slim foundation of fact: a look at cowboy humor' which was produced in cooperation with KUAT AM. It is a half hour show which has received national distribution and aired July, 1982. The program was produced in May of 1982 by James S. Griffith and Cephas Bowles of KUAT. It features stories, tall tales, and a song performed by five old-time Arizona cowboys: the late Van Holyoak of Clay Springs; Everett Brisendine of Chino Valley; Marvin Bennett of Mayer; Gail Gardner of Prescott; and Dick Denny who is now a resident of Australia. James S. Griffith serves as narrator and the music is provided by Tucon's own Ed Smith and Dean Armstrong"... Transcript located in file 83.6/C.1.T...

did.abstract: NOTES: From acquisitions file: "Tape... of cowboy songs performed by the late Romaine Lowdermilk (sic), pioneer Arizona dude rancher. Lowdermilk recorded (in the 50's?) at Audio-Video Recording Studios in Phoenix [and] left the masters with them. Guests and fans of Lowdermilk's, desiring an LP of his singing would order custom pressings... Lowdermilk is referred to extensively in John I. White's "Get along, little doggies: Songs and songmakers of the American West", University of Illinois Press, 1975"... Session logs on two typed pages are at SWF 009, 98.15/M.1. Source: James S. Griffith.

did.unittitle: In Loving Memory of Mrs. Rosie Johnson - Southside Presbyterian Church Choir - Tucson, Arizona, Vol II, Southside Presbyterian Church Choir - Tucson, Arizona.
did.physdesc: 1 sound cassette, analog, 1 7/8 ips
did.abstract: Commercial cassette recording of the Southside Presbyterian Church Choir in Tucson, Arizona. Recording date unknown. The recording is dedicated to the memory of African American gospel singer Rosie Johnson who was a featured performer at the Tucson Meet Yourself festivals in the 1980s and 1990s. CONTENTS: Side A: O It Is Jesus -- I Love to Praise Him -- Twelve Gates -- We Shall Walk -- Swing Low, Sweet Chariot -- Lift Him Up -- Lead Me, Guide Me -- Love Has No Borders -- Side B: You Must Be Born Again -- Call Him Up -- Mother’s Amazing Grace -- There’s A Bright Side -- Up Above My Head -- Wade In The Water -- Be Not Afraid. Source: James S. Griffith.

CONTENTS: Side A: Sonora Querida -- El Canal del Infiernillo -- El Corrido del Guasiado -- Tololoche Chicoteado -- Recuerdo de Amor -- La Yaquecita -- Side B: La Barca de Guaymas -- Cielito Lindo -- Solamente Una Vez -- Volver, Volver -- El Rancho Grande -- Quisiera Amarte Menos.
